content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: simple in Python but cool

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept the contribution because I like the typical solving

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice easy clash. Can be done in any language of course.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Some languages support operations on big numbers, others don't so it would make a big difference in cod size and even speed. This site has a lot of binary problems. Introduce a new mechanic to make it original.

The goal must say which is the lowest bit.

In general, the input could add a line with "BigEndian" and "LittleEndian" for provide it dynamically and add complexity to this clash (because missing 0 are leading or trailing)

you can also change the Example for having a better example with the endianess (11 + 1 give the same result in both endianess)
Maybe explain that binary strings represents unsigned integers

Test and validators named "Huge " failed in PHP due to the restriction limit for big numbers.
Please change them.

- There are excessive binary-like computational problems on CodinGame already, and I don't see any innovative ideas presented here. For example: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/21566380bc46eee8941023cf60ffb10863b7

- Recommended to add definition for binary string:
Binary String is a sequence of 0's and 1's to denote the value of number in {{Base 2}}.

- Please format [[a.length]] and [[b.length]]

- Please provide a test with 0 as a or b for Reverse Mode players.
ty

Should be [[a]].length and [[b]].length.

Other than that, I totally agree with whitecard's suggestions. All very valid points.

Also, in Constraints section, you may format 0 and 1 as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

Thanks.
There is no need to use big numbers, this problem can be solved easily using only strings.
the additional input is a really neat idea, would love to see it implemented!

I get what you're trying to say, but that is an issue one can't really go around. It is inherit to either language design or the standard libraries these languages come with. Let's take the most obvious example of C and Python. Where a C program would take at least couple of lines of code just to be able to compile the file, a full Python solution could take a single line.

In fastest and reverse modes, do you think that young devs will know how to do it ? 
For sure, they will use the functions bindec() or base_convert(). The right solution to deal with big binary numbers in PHP is to use base_convert()... BUT, they will use for sure the basic '+' to add the two numbers, and it will fail... Young PHP coders do not know the function bcadd() to treat big numbers... And, for chance, if they know this function (that is quite impossible), the result of the sum of the "Huge" test is 1284445756884290447649037105003099045734848310583395551441385091250296290451566050. 
This number cannot be treated in PHP due to the restriction limit for big numbers.
One solution in PHP is to treat the numbers like this : https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/program-to-add-two-binary-strings/

A good CoC should be fair between languages... After all, it is a CoC in fastest mode...

In Ruby, it is not difficult to do :
    puts (a.to_i(2)+b.to_i(2)).to_s(2)

So, do you think it is fair for young PHP devs which are learning ?

I did it quickly without reading statement because I saw the 'reverse' mode.

I first just printed inputs in error stream and saw immediately that 'Huge' test contains more than 64 bits values and so I immediately implemented a solution only with strings.

If you know how to add by hand two binary numbers and know basics of string manipulation in your predilected language it is not a problem at all...and if it not the case you can still learn it (after all, being faced with new challenges and learning and leveling up your knowledge...that's one of the purposes of clashes...no?)

If you feel disavantaged in 'shortest' mode with your predilected language, learn another one...that is what many users do to win in this mode (both confirmed and beginners developers).
I do not talk about me but young PHP devs... They are actually learning PHP, do you think they will learn another language just for CodinGame ? :)

I didn't talk about you, I'm generalizing...

Why not ?...there are a few opportunities like trying to solve 15 puzzles in a specific language to get the related achievements.

I understand your point of view...
This specific issue for big numbers in PHP could be solved by editing the php.ini file
I think Stub Generator already hinted the use of strings? Or does PHP's String datatype ambiguous with Integer?

Yes, in PHP, string datatype and integer are ambiguous because PHP is permissive.
i.e. :
$a='1010';
»» this variable is considered in the same time as a string AND an integer because it contains only digits...

While reading the solution in JS, we can see that each variable is converted in decimal number. For JS, there is a special function (BigInt()) to treat big numbers. 
As we spoke together in antoher clash, PHP is limited, by default, for numbers. So, it would be cool from the author to limit the numbers in a 32 bit system (or even 64).

The solution to treat this clash in PHP only by string will take a long time, whereas in JS, Python, Ruby, (and maybe others languages), it will take few seconds to write the answer
Ah I see.

"A good CoC should be fair between languages"

It's never the case.
The "shortest code" was always a pain in Java :)  So, it's the game.

If it was, i will do the opposite by adding a "very high" addition with like 50000 bits for each strings
